title: VANPY: Voice Analysis Framework
author: Gregory Koushnir (Ben-Gurion University of the Negev), Michael Fire (Ben-Gurion University of the Negev), Galit Fuhrmann Alpert (Ben-Gurion University of the Negev), Dima Kagan (Ben-Gurion University of the Negev), ...
relevance_why: This paper presents a comprehensive voice analysis framework that integrates various voice processing techniques, relevant to Haohe Liu's research on audio generation and manipulation.
background: The task involves automated analysis of voice data to extract speaker characteristics such as gender, age, height, and emotion.
contribution: The paper introduces the VANPY framework to solve automated voice analysis challenges, achieving seamless integration of multiple voice analysis components.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous frameworks primarily focused on either basic preprocessing or classification tasks but lacked comprehensive integration of both.
technical_comparison.novelty: The VANPY framework uniquely combines preprocessing, feature extraction, and classification to facilitate robust speaker characterization.

key_innovation: VANPY's modular design allows for easy extension and integration of new voice analysis components, enhancing its versatility and applicability.
real_world_impact: The framework could greatly improve voice-based applications, including health monitoring and human-computer interaction by providing accurate speaker characterization.
limitations: Although the models demonstrate robust performance, they do not surpass state-of-the-art performance.

new_terms.Voice Activity Detection (VAD): **Voice Activity Detection (VAD)** is a technique used to detect the presence or absence of human speech in audio recordings, crucial for speech recognition systems.

open_sourcing: The code is available at https://github.com/griko/vanpy
